column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Internal combustion engines ( ICE ) are the main propulsion systems in road transport .
#Text=In mid-2017 , Serrano referred to the impossibility of replacing them as the power plant in most vehicles .
#Text=Nowadays , this statement is true even when considering the best growth scenario for all-electric and hybrid vehicles .

#Text=The arguments supporting this position consider the growing demand for transport , the strong development of cleaner and more efficient ICEs , the availability of fossil fuels , and the high energy density of said conventional fuels .
#Text=Overall , there seems to be strong arguments to support the medium-long-term viability of ICEs as the predominant power plant for road transport applications .
#Text=However , the situation has changed dramatically in the last few years .
#Text=The media and other market players are claiming the death of ICEs in the mid-term .
#Text=Politicians from several G7 countries , such as France , Spain , and the United Kingdom , have announced the prohibition of ICEs in their markets , in some cases , as early as 2040 .
#Text=Large cities , such London , Paris , Madrid , and Berlin , are also considering severe limits to ICE-powered vehicles .
#Text=What is the analysis that can be made from this new situation ?
#Text=1. What Is the Problem with ICE ( Internal Combustion Engines ) ?
#Text=The media ’s arguments against ICEs range from the need to reduce CO2 emissions ( global warming ) to the need to improve the air quality in cities ( NOx and particulate matter emissions ) .
#Text=Much of this debate about the future of ICEs has arisen from the Dieselgate scandal .
#Text=A horrible wrong decision from a management and engineering point of view at a specific time and place has generated a worldwide butterfly effect in the automotive industry .
#Text=However , making the problem a virtue , Dieselgate has forced new regulations to obtain much more efficient and cleaner ICEs .

#Text=As commonly takes place , old and lax pollutant regulations have now resulted in a pendular effect toward radically contrary positions , delighting the media and generating excessive political reactions without a clear scientific basis .
#Text=All this is reflected in the look to publish a sufficiently popular or good news novelty .
#Text=We could define the situation as energy populism .

#Text=Although new regulations that force ICE technology to be more environmentally friendly must always be welcome , prohibitions motivated by a poor diagnosis of the situation will not help at all , neither to improve air quality nor to mitigate global warming .
#Text=2. What Is the Problem with Electric Vehicles ?
#Text=What should be the alternative to the current ICE in the mid-to-long term ?
#Text=Combining the pendulum effect of public opinion with the excellent marketing of new actors in the passenger car sector , a confusion cocktail is served for the media .
#Text=After all , one might ask if the use of the conventional propulsive systems over 120 years was the right path .
#Text=How can such an old concept be innovative ?
#Text=How can the ICE be great and technologically advanced at burning fossil fuels ?
#Text=An easy but wrong conclusion comes without the need of reflection : Let us welcome “ new electric motors and batteries ” in zero-emission cars !
#Text=The bad news is that energy is neither created nor destroyed , only transformed .
#Text=Electric motors and batteries are not new , nor are they clean and , in general , are not free from problems .
#Text=One can directly identify two relevant problems .
#Text=The first problem is that vehicle propulsion involves energy transformations and the electric motor does not use a primary energy source but an energy vector .

#Text=Although public opinion has a clear idea of how some processes like friction can negatively affect transport applications , the understanding of the impact of the second law of thermodynamics is limited .

#Text=The problem is that electricity must be produced , most usually from non-renewable energy sources , which equals around 60 % in energy losses , and then transported , which adds 20 % of additional losses .
#Text=Unfortunately , renewable sources are barely 10 % of the global energy mix , as observed in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=without a medium-term forecast of significant increase .

#Text=In some countries like the USA , China , Russia , Poland , South Korea , or Germany , fossil fuels , including a good percentage of coal , remain the largest source of energy as a raw material for electricity production .
#Text=In a first approach , the only G8 country with real alternatives to CO2-emitting technologies is France due to its continued commitment with nuclear energy .

#Text=Therefore , with the current energy mix and with an analysis of the complete life cycle , the so-called analysis from the cradle to the grave , the alternative to electric motors will not eliminate global CO2 emissions .
